ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed very strong close-reading and writing skills, definitely can analyze each work to dissect each philosopher's thoughts in this overall very well-taught course.
This course helped me improve the clarity of my philosophical argumentation quite a bit.
Better writing and analysis skills

I developed my close reading skills, analytical thinking, and expanded my vocabulary. I also feel like my worldview has changed and expanded to incorporate the thought of the thinkers we read. Also, I finally gained confidence in my ability to write a philosophical paper.
This course helped me to develop my critical thinking in regards to philosophical texts and thinking.
This course tackles the fundamental questions of modern philosophy, but my biggest growth was in my ability to systematically tackle logical questions and analyze portions of text through my essays.

I learned about the relationship between philosophy in the modern era to that in the ancient one. I learned about how different types of thinkers ground their philosophies, their metrics for morality, and much more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths - amazing staff, great content, insightful discussions 
weaknesses - workload, definitely became difficult to manage at times
This course was excellent - Professor Franks is a fantastic professor who is highly engaged with his students and the material. The only weakness of this course was that it was online.

Weakness: SO MUCH reading! More focused/specific/shorter assignments would be better I think. Also Kant is IMPOSSIBLE it would be helpful to have some extra resources for understanding him.

Strength: Professor Franks made amazing slideshows and really cared that we understood the material

Although this is not the fault of Professor Franks at all, I would have appreciated if for the longer texts, there were instructions on which parts were important to focus on. Often I would get a bit bogged down with all the arguments, wondering which were most pivotal.

This course covers a wide breadth of thinkers and places them conversation with each other very well. I felt that the bulk of reading, especially in the later weeks where we were reading entire books which were then boiled down to key passages or insights, inhibited my ability to get the most of the class.
Two strengths were the works we studied in the course and Professor Frank's commitment to making sure we understood them. It could be improved by involving more student discussion in each class.

The course had us read the most random of pages sometimes. There would be an entire paragraph outlining us to read like 4 pages in one chapter, under 3 in another, and so on. I feel as if there are better ways to teach similar material without having us read a glimpse of many sections. Then again, this is a super minor complaint.

Beside that I think we read a good array of authors from different regions with different thoughts, so overall pretty good.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures went fairly well - seminars would be much better if they were in person.
I think this class was taught the best that it could be under the virtual circumstances.

I think that the recorded lecture style works extremely well. It was easy to fit the lecture into my personal studying schedule, easy to review important points, and easy to follow along with the provided notes. However, engagement is difficult in an online course no matter what, so I did feel that our classes sometimes had low energy.

Screensharing powerpoints was a good way to teach the material, but it's unfortunate that he cannot take questions during the mini presentations without someone just calling out. Seems much less natural, but good enough for the circumstances.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes I would! I learned a lot as someone not so philosophically inclined.

I would recommend this course to anyone at all who is interested in the humanities, even if they are not planning on majoring in philosophy. The understanding of how intellectual currents flow throughout history, and how different thinkers are shaped by each other in different historical periods, is invaluable to any student of culture.
YES! DS is an amazing course and develops an individual both as a student and as a person.
I would recommend this class! I thought our readings in second semester philosophy were more interesting than those of first semester. I also loved Prof. Franks' teaching style.
I definitely would. I really enjoyed getting to know the works we studied in Professor Franks' section, especially because his commitment to both the works and to our learning was clear.
Probably. It was interesting to read the authors, and they all made me think more about the world around me and what truly is important. It's good knowledge for anyone to ponder over.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: recorded lecture and discussion section (virtual)
virtual lectures
1x week recorded lecture, 2x week virtual seminar
Recorded lecture
Recorded lectures
Weekly recorded lecture
